case_vignette:
A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days. During this time, he had three episodes of blood in his urine. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis after a positive routine tuberculin skin test, and he was treated accordingly. His maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not take any medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard at both lung bases. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Urea nitrogen 32 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.5 mg/dL
Urine
Protein 2+
Blood 3+
RBC casts numerous
WBC casts negative
A chest x-ray shows patchy, pulmonary infiltrates bilaterally. A renal biopsy in this patient shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?" (From the American Board of Internal Medicine, 2001)
The patient is a 24-year-old person who comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days. During this time, he or she had three episodes of blood in the urine. Six years ago, he or she was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis after a positive routine tuberculin skin test, and he or she was treated accordingly. His or her maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not take any medications. His or her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard at both lung bases. Laboratory studies show:

Creatinine 3.5 mg/dL
Urine

question: What is the final diagnosis?

Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past 10 days. I also had three episodes of blood in my urine during this time.
Do you have any history of kidney disease or kidney stones?
No, I don't have any history of kidney disease or kidney stones.
Have you been diagnosed with any chronic diseases, such as diabetes, hypertension, or autoimmune conditions?
Six years ago, I was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis, but no other chronic diseases like diabetes, hypertension, or autoimmune conditions. My maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus.
Are you currently on any medication, and have you taken any treatments for tuberculosis in the past?
I am not currently taking any medications, but I was treated for latent tuberculosis six years ago after a positive skin test.
Do you experience any other symptoms like joint pain, rashes, or changes in weight?
No, I do not experience joint pain, rashes, or changes in weight.
Final Diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome
